article.title: Effects of random potentials in three-dimensional quantum electrodynamics

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the different line types in this Feynman diagram represent?
choices: Solid line: Gauge boson propagator; Wavy line: Free fermion propagator
Solid line: Free fermion propagator; Wavy line: Gauge boson propagator
Solid line: Random mass; Wavy line: Gauge coupling
Solid line: Fermion self-energy; Wavy line: Polarization tensor

multiple_choice_question.text: What type of interaction does each subfigure in this Feynman diagram represent?
choices: (a) Random potential; (b) Gauge interaction
(a) Gauge interaction; (b) Random potential
(a) Fermion self-energy; (b) Polarization tensor
(a) Vertex correction; (b) Self-energy correction

multiple_choice_question.text: What does this Feynman diagram depict?
choices: One-loop corrections to the gauge coupling
One-loop corrections to the fermion self-energy
One-loop corrections to the polarization tensor
One-loop corrections to the fermion-disorder vertex

multiple_choice_question.text: What type of correction is being calculated in this Feynman diagram?
choices: Gauge interaction correction to the gauge coupling
Gauge interaction correction to the fermion-disorder vertex
Random potential correction to the fermion self-energy
Random potential correction to the polarization tensor

multiple_choice_question.text: What does this figure illustrate about the behavior of random mass (RM)?
choices: RM is always irrelevant, regardless of the gauge interaction.
RM becomes marginally relevant in the presence of gauge interaction.
RM has no fixed points and flows to infinity.
RM exhibits a stable fixed point only in the absence of gauge interaction.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the effect of gauge interaction and random vector potential (RVP) on the fermion velocity (UF) in the presence of RM?
choices: Both enhance the suppression of UF at low energies.
Both have negligible effect on the behavior of UF.
Gauge interaction enhances UF while RVP suppresses it.
Gauge interaction suppresses UF while RVP enhances it.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the behavior of random scalar potential (RSP) as the energy scale changes?
choices: RSP flows to a stable fixed point at low energies.
RSP exhibits a runaway flow and drives a diffusive phase transition.
RSP remains constant and does not affect the system.
RSP is completely suppressed by the gauge interaction.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does this figure demonstrate about the fermion velocity (UF) in the presence of RSP and RVP?
choices: UF increases with decreasing energy scale.
UF remains constant regardless of the energy scale.
UF is enhanced by RSP and suppressed by RVP.
UF is suppressed and eventually vanishes at a finite energy scale.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main conclusion drawn from this schematic flow diagram regarding the interplay between RM and RSP?
choices: RM and RSP both flow to stable fixed points at low energies.
RM dominates at low energies and suppresses the effect of RSP.
RSP dominates at low energies and suppresses the effect of RM.
RM and RSP have negligible effect on the system in the presence of gauge interaction.
